items.title: Aung San Suu Kyi looks to Myanmar poll victory at climax of lifelong campaign
items.summary:
NLD is expected to sweep to power this weekend, but she is barred from the presidency – and may not carry the same love she did 25 years ago

When Aung San Suu Kyi was asked to take part in demonstrations against Myanmar’s brutal treatment of activists during a 1988 student uprising, she replied: “It’s not my sort of thing.”

Yet more than a quarter of a century later – most of that time spent alone under house arrest and some on hunger strike – the 70-year-old known as “the Lady” is anticipating a political victory this weekend against the country’s army-backed government.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Aung San Suu Kyi looks to Myanmar poll victory at climax of lifelong campaign

source.title: Network Front | The Guardian
source.subtitle: Latest international news, sport and comment from the Guardian

items.title: Walking in a Welsh rainforest
items.summary:
You don’t have to go to Brazil to trek through a rainforest – Snowdonia has its very own wet woodland just waiting to be explored

Does the phrase “save the rainforest” conjure up visions of: a) Brazil, b) Borneo, or c) north Wales? You may not know it but Britain is home to 70,000 hectares (173,000 acres) of rainforest, in areas including western Scotland, Cumbria, south-west England and, yes, north Wales. And these temperate forests are just as precious – and under just as much threat – as their tropical counterparts.

I travelled to Maentwrog, a tiny village in Snowdonia, to visit two neighbouring woodlands, Llennyrch and Coed Felinrhyd (also known as Melenrhyd). The woods date back an astonishing 10,000 years to the last ice age. These ancient places, found above the Vale of Ffestiniog, are two of Europe’s best remaining examples of Atlantic oak woodland, otherwise known as temperate rainforest. They are wet and wild: crisscrossed with streams and gullies, bordered by the Ceunant Llennyrch gorge, drenched with river spray and more than 200 days of rain a year. On the autumn afternoon that I visited, it was unseasonably hot and humid, making it feel as though we were stepping into the jungle – I half-expected to glimpse a tiger through the ferns.

Continue reading...

source.title: Network Front | The Guardian
source.subtitle: Latest international news, sport and comment from the Guardian

items.title: Xi Jinping says China wants South China Sea issue resolved peacefully
items.summary:
China has the confidence and ability to maintain the peace and stability of the South China Sea area, China’s president tells neighbours during tour

China wants to resolve the South China Sea dispute peacefully but the government has a responsibility to protect the country’s sovereignty and maritime rights, president Xi Jinping has said.

Related: How China's artificial islands led to tension in the South China Sea

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Xi Jinping says China wants South China Sea issue resolved peacefully

items.title: US senator's claims Australia is being greedy over trade deal rejected
items.summary:
Orrin Hatch, a Republican senator unhappy that IP protections for some medicines were not extended, says the deal may have to be renegotiated

The federal government has hit back as a key US senator accusing Australia of being “greedy” threatens to reject the Trans-Pacific Partnership deal.

Orrin Hatch, a Republican who chairs the US Senate finance committee and whose support will be crucial to passing the deal, is unhappy that intellectual property protections for biologic medicines have not been extended to 12 years.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: US senator's claims Australia is being greedy over trade deal rejected

items.title: 'No record label, no promotion, no merch, no reason not to tour Japan'
items.summary:
Brisbane band Toxic Bears are serious about their music, less so about the music business ... or turning a profit

Some people go to church. We play in a band. If you haven’t seen Toxic Bears down at Brews Bros (our friend’s microbrewery in Brisbane where the cops have stopped bands playing now anyway), chances are you haven’t seen us.

We merge punk with Latin, funk, Jamaican disco, the Purdie shuffle. Write songs about real life encounters with bikies, shock jocks, wannabe gigolos and Dame Stella Rimington.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: 'No record label, no promotion, no merch, no reason not to tour Japan'

items.title: Hillary Clinton seeks to outflank liberal rivals at Democratic forum
items.summary:
• Clinton tacks left on police violence and corporate influence
  • Bernie Sanders defends gun control position
  • Martin O’Malley takes sideswipe at Clinton on Keystone XL pipeline

Hillary Clinton moved to the left on Friday night as the Democratic frontrunner took stronger and more impassioned stances than in the past on police violence and corporate influence in the United States.

Before a lively crowd of nearly 3,000 in South Carolina, the former secretary of state struck some of her most populist tones of the campaign while participating in what was possibly the strangest televised live event of the election season so far.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Hillary Clinton seeks to outflank liberal rivals at Democratic forum

items.title: Protests in Taiwan as Ma prepares for historic meeting with Xi Jinping
items.summary:
Protesters tried to storm parliament in Taiwan amid anger over their leader’s summit with the Chinese president – the first such meeting since the 1949 split

Protesters have tried to storm the parliament building in Taiwan as the island’s leader Ma Ying-jeou prepares to meet Chinese president Xi Jinping for a historic summit in Singapore.

Related: China initiates Taiwan meeting as South China Sea tensions rise

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Protests in Taiwan as Ma prepares for historic meeting with Xi Jinping

items.title: Mexican rights agency investigates 150 bodies of crime victims found in pits
items.summary:
The bodies were discovered in the central state of Morelos when the family of a murdered kidnap victim demanded the return of their loved one’s remains

A state human rights agency has begun an investigation into why about 150 bodies of crime victims were dumped into pits in central Mexico.

Some of the bodies may have been buried in the mass graves simply to clean out a state morgue. But some of the bodies lacked the case file markers they are supposed to be buried with, leading to questions about how they died.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Mexican rights agency investigates 150 bodies of crime victims found in pits

source.title: Network Front | The Guardian
source.subtitle: Latest international news, sport and comment from the Guardian

items.title: Ukuleles are the devil’s tool – but I’m making one anyway
items.summary:
Yes they’re twee and annoying, but I want my son to be a musical genius so he can support me in my old age. This uke is for him

Full disclosure: I know, OK? I’m making a ukulele. Yes, I know how unacceptable that is. At this stage, ukuleles are basically the devil’s tool. They’re irritatingly popular at the moment and the curse that currently plagues 90% of twee advertising jingles. I know, OK? I know.

And yet, I’m still making a ukulele. I’m making it so that I can give it to my son, in the vain hope that he’ll come to love music and write an international number-one hit and use the proceeds to look after me in my old age because I’m jiggered if I’ve got a pension yet. So, yes, I’m making a ukulele this month. Suck it up.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Ukuleles are the devil’s tool – but I’m making one anyway

source.title: Network Front | The Guardian
source.subtitle: Latest international news, sport and comment from the Guardian

items.title: Dozens missing in BHP-Vale mine disaster in Brazil as rescue continues
items.summary:
Rescuers continue search for survivors after flooding from two collapsed dams used by mines owned by BHP Billiton and Vale swept through six villages

Rescue teams searched through mud and debris on Friday for dozens of people missing after a pair of dams collapsed at a Brazilian mine owned by two of the world’s biggest iron ore producers.

Walls of water filled with mining waste cascaded downhill when the dams burst on Thursday, engulfing a nearby village in a sea of mud and flooding others far removed from the open-pit Samarco mine jointly owned by BHP Billiton and Vale.

Continue reading...

alternate.title: Dozens missing in BHP-Vale mine disaster in Brazil as rescue continues

source.title: Network Front | The Guardian
source.subtitle: Latest international news, sport and comment from the Guardian
